comentarios: NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a very short but cute and sweet visual novel. It is a kinetic novel that uses the E-Mote system much better than in some other works that I've read (notably Study Steady). It also features animated H scenes (there are 3 in this volume).

comentarios: This visual novel is fairly bare bones past the E-Mote system. There's only a few BGM used, and not a lot of CGs are used. However, what it has it uses pretty well. I personally didn't utilize it more than a few times, but you can press "p" and see the characters on screen show off the "physics engine". It's full of cute scenes as well as a tiny bit of drama (nothing crazy though). I would recommend this visual novel to anyone who just wants a comfy relaxing read, or who has a predilection for catgirls in particular.

comentarios: [h1]Is this game worth it without the 18+ DLC?[/h1]  I would say so.  More specifically, I would say the game had enough of a plot (or at least a series of random though somewhat related events that appeared in sequence, but in a fun way) and the characters had enough personality to them to enjoy for its own sake, and there is some meaning to this besides [i]just[/i] being an excuse for naughty moments.  [h1]My personal random ramblings[/h1]  Enough of me pretending to be helpful to other players, now it's time for me to vent about my experience playing the game. You may as well stop reading here, because the rest of this review somewhat doesn't matter (though I guess it does mildly touch upon certain things that happen in the game, but honestly the main takeaway here is just "Playing without the 18+ DLC doesn't mean it's suddenly family friendly, it's just more like 17+ instead").  So, to start with, the way I even heard about this game in the first place was that occasionally I'll check old forum threads where people are recommending games in categories I'm interested in or I'll look through interesting curator lists and stuff looking for new ideas for games to play, and a name that kept popping up over and over was Nekopara, Nekopara. The title alone didn't seem that interesting at first glance, so I just ignored it, but the name just kept popping up over and over in different places, Nekopara, Nekopara, and this was mentioned far more than most games to the point where I finally decided to see what it was everyone was going on about, and I look and, eh, it's just some catgirl game, nothing that special, really.  Still, there's a demo, so I may as well try it out just to see what all the fuss is about, and normally I'm the kind of guy who plays a demo for 90 seconds and if the game hasn't captured my interest by then I just quit and move on, but this time I was going to take it super seriously because this was a big big demo in my mind, not just for this random game that the entire "young lonely anime obsessed male" population seems to adore, but also a demo for essentially the entire "Because you don't have a girlfriend, here's an anime girl instead" (not that I'm trying to be unkind to the playerbase here, but it's certainly true that I don't have a girlfriend and I played this game, and that should say enough) visual novel genre as a whole, because looking into the genre, a lot of other games looked vaguely as interesting as Nekopara but didn't have demos and so if what I assume is one of the most popular and therefore likely best games in the genre didn't seem interesting I'd just forget about those other ones too.  So, I'm playing the demo, and it's good or whatever, I guess, and then I get to the end (equivalent to the end of chapter 1 in the full game) when Chocola is telling generic protagonist that she wants to stay with him, and I admit I rather enjoyed that scene and I thought the backstory when the catgirls were younger was cute and I thought it was really really sweet the way Chocola loves her master so much, and, yeah, it was a bit heavy handed and they didn't have to say 700 times that these were her true honest feelings, but still, it was probably better to go too heavy than too light there and so I enjoyed it and so fine game you win and I'll wishlist you.  A little later I eventually get around to buying the full game, and I'm playing it without the 18+ DLC, and I must say my general impression with adult games (mostly because I'd heard about a couple of RPG's where it's apparently possible to do a pure run, but I guess maybe I shouldn't generalize that sort of thing) was that there will often be a choice to watch a naughty scene with little impact on the plot or just skip it, and I thought I had even noticed a point in the demo where such a choice might occur, because there's a point where the catgirls are asking generic protagonist to take a bath with them and he says no without any input from the player but I had figured at the time that maybe if you were playing the full game and had the 18+ DLC you'd have the opportunity to say yes there for a naughty scene if you'd like, and I just figured the whole game would be like that with mostly normal goings on interspersed with random smut occasionally, but then actually playing, uhh... no, that's not the game at all, and the smut is baked into the main plot here and most noticeably a whole big thing is made out of the catgirls going into heat and desperately needing a partner as a flimsy excuse for generic protagonist to say "I guess it can't be helped" and heading off to satisfy them, and without the 18+ DLC we don't actually see this happen but the game just skips to them lying in bed afterwards, but it's still implied, and honestly it was personally a bit of a disappointment for me because I'm the kind of guy who when they care for a character wants to see them stay pure and innocent, but at least my girls seemed happy about it, I guess. I just hope generic protagonist continues to take good care of them.  More than that, though, I was surprised by how much stuff made it into this game even without the 18+ DLC: There's a scene of generic protagonist washing off the catgirls after an incredibly forced situation to get them dirty that any idiot should have seen coming a mile away and that generic protagonist should have known to stop well in advance, but my point is the girls are totally naked here and there's a full illustration for it, and, yeah, due to the angle and some convenient steam and stuff nothing "interesting" is visible here, but it was still really hot and I enjoyed it anyway and I still wouldn't want my mom to see that image as my desktop background.  Also, there's weirdly a scene of one of the catgirls, well... "having a good time by herself", let's call it, and I have no idea if that scene might be more explicit with the 18+ DLC or something, but as I saw it, there was no special illustration or anything but just the usual character model with its arms extending beneath the bottom of the screen suggestively and some obligatory moaning and whatnot, but that was still more than I was expecting here.  Also, there's a scene of two of the characters talking about reproduction, which mostly centers around plants, but one of the characters is getting way too into it and drooling at the thought and stuff anyway.  Random thing, but generic protagonist's little sister kept making weird inappropriate comments to him, and it wasn't a major element to the story and I don't [i]think[/i] she was serious, but I still thought that felt weird, not just without the 18+ DLC, but just in general because although I realize that we who are into brother-sister stuff are not an insignificant group in the lonely young guys community, I also realize that there are plenty of people who aren't and such a taboo tends to be rather strong (not to mention she's specifically referred to as a kid at least once), and so I thought it a strange choice to include that in the game for such little reason and potentially alienate some of the players who were just here for the totally normal human on animal action (seriously, a fairly big deal is made about how catgirls are seen more as cat than girl, and I noticed in the Japanese text at least once them being referred to with a counter for animals, and it seems strange to me that if you wanted to have relations with catgirls that you would do so with a mindset that focuses more on the cat than on the girl) rather than the somehow less normal brother on sister lack of action (because for the record, generic protagonist isn't into the stuff his sister says, but he'd rather she knocked it off).  Also, there's a gratuitous double panty shot.  Anyway, near the end there's a scene where the catgirls are threatened with arrest while trying to help their master, and I thought their dedication to him was sweet there too.

comentarios: 10/10  Wholesome and fun from start to finish! The characters here really stand out — none of that boring stereotype stuff you usually see in medium-tier VNs. The writing isn’t some grand masterpiece, but it nails its cozy, lighthearted vibe. Each catgirl has her own quirky personality that keeps things fresh and entertaining. If you’re looking for warm feelings and cute interactions, this is the one to start with. Buy the patch

comentarios: NekoPara Vol. 1 marks a charming and polished entry into the main story of the series, introducing players to Kashou Minaduki as he opens his new pâtisserie, La Soleil. The narrative centers around his unexpected companions, Chocola and Vanilla — two energetic and devoted catgirls — who insist on helping him run the shop. What unfolds is a sweet and often humorous tale of affection, adjustment, and the growing bond between the characters.

comentarios: Visually stunning with beautifully detailed artwork and fluid Live2D animations, Vol. 1 also benefits from excellent Japanese voice acting and a soothing soundtrack that complements its cozy, romantic atmosphere. Whether you're in it for the heartwarming story or the adorable interactions, NekoPara Vol. 1 offers a feel-good experience that's as relaxing as it is endearing.

Don't worry I was unlucky enough to buy all the volumes grouped on a sale, so I can safely say the story doesn't get much better in the later volumes. comentarios: Calling Nekopara a "game" is a stretch; simply put, it's an illustrated story you get to sit back and enjoy. Even as far as visual novels go, there's no choices to be made, and really not that much to do except click through the dialogue.  But, as far as the visuals go, it definitely delivers: the characters are all adorable, the artstyle is a treat, and the story is cute, fun and lighthearted. And of course, the H-scenes are very well animated, though you can choose to exclude those if they're not your thing.  A great purchase for cat girl lovers who live by the motto of "cute girls doing cute things".

comentarios: I don't like leaving negative reviews but I feel like I have to for this one. Strap in, It's a frustrated one.  For those who don't want to read the whole thing, I can summarise this [strike] game [/strike] Visual novel (Seriously, why does it not have the tag visual novel (as a main tag)):  [h1] Shallow [/h1]   I will be honest and say I don't like visual novels in general, so you might ask me why would I even bother buying this? Well, It was and still is popular and well liked, I did really like ddlc, and I like erotic material. I figured when seeing it in a bundled sale of all volumes that I might like it and perhaps that it could even change my mind on visual novels. REST ASSURED, It reinforced my aversion.  [h3] The good [/h3] - The voice actresses are good from what I can tell, but I don't speak Japanese so take that as you will. - I like the art. It's well made apart from 2 nitpicks that I will mention later.  [h3] The bad (not 18+) [/h3] - The story is so shallow. I guess the best way to describe the story is interpersonal relationships between the protagonist and the catgirls + sister. That is all. What does this mean for the story? Well, it means that there is practically nothing going on. When the story works up to something, the chapter ends and the goal has been achieved off screen. Phenomenal. - It's a visual novel, I know, but it should still be mentioned: there is 0 interactibility. None. Forget replay value, there isn't even ANY playing. - Any shallow or minimal conflict there is, will be resolved within max. 10 sentences. - The book is about 6-7 hours on auto-play (with 18+). Considering there is no reason to replay this or the fact that it is just reading, €9,75 is quite a lot to ask. SIKE, to get this full time you need the 18+ patch which costs ANOTHER €9,75 for a total of €19,50. - The story doesn't respect your time. What is told, could be done in 3 hours probably. - The MC is a dolt, I dislike him. - I know this is a nitpick, but hear me out. One of the painted backgrounds, the one that shows the front of the store, has an opening sign that states: 'opem'. There aren't many backgrounds, it's a simple word, the only focus for this product is writing, the art, and voice acting. Frankly, there is no reason to have such a basic mistake. - 90%+ of the story is just happy go lucky. (Maybe somewhat individual criticism, but it feels off)  [h3] The bad (18+) [/h3] - I hope you like bleeding eardrums, because that is the main 18+ experience. The exceptionally whiny and earpiercing 'wails' will drive you up a wall. Lowering your volume won't help due to the high pitch of the voice actresses. - From what I understand the dialogue is very much Japanese style... They want it but still will say stop, no and stuff... yuck. - Something that has always bothered me about hentai, let's describe literally everything in excruciating detail. They just don't know when to shut up. - I hope you like censoring. The good animated scenes are utterly worthless as a result, you can't even see anything (apart from nips). Honestly, just look up the 6 gifs online, it might even be a better experience. - I hope you like repeating sentences that are only minimally altered. (x4) - The official patch for the 18+ material is another €9,75! Are you out of your mind? To be honest, it's somewhat my mistake to think it was included. Yes, the game is practically known for the funneh 18+ stuff but let it be known, it costs extra.  [h1] To conclude [/h1]  I feel like my review was more articulate than the slideshow I paid for. Keep your money, it isn't worth the sweet catgirl tiddies.  There are enough of those and 100x better quality online for free.

comentarios: Nekopara is a super chill VN for catgirl lovers. The art style is adorable (those CGs tho ), and the characters are total sweethearts – their banter feels cozy AF. Voice acting slaps (JP dub crew rise up!), and the soundtrack is pure comfy vibes. Plot’s light but wholesome, like a warm cup of tea with extra nyaa~. Perfect for short play sessions or unwinding after a long day. Heads up: Some scenes might make you side-eye your screen if others are watching . Overall, a cute, low-stakes visual novel. 9/10 fluffiness, would recommend for slice-of-life fans

comentarios: {\__/} ( • - •)   /つ ❤ [b] Nekopara Vol. 1 [/b] [b] Introduction [/b] Nekopara (Japanese: ネコぱら) is a series of visual novels developed by Neko Works and published by Sekai Project. The first game in the series, Nekopara Vol. 1, was released in December 2014.[1] The series is set in a world where humans live alongside catgirls, known as "Nekos". An all-ages anime OVA adaptation was released on Steam in December 2017; it became one of the top earners in Steam in December 2017. An anime television series adaptation by Felix Film premiered from January to March 2020. The anime is licensed in English-speaking regions by Funimation.  [b] Vol. 1 [/b] Kashou Minaduki is an aspiring chef who moves away from home to open his own confection shop. While he is unpacking in his new shop, he discovers that two of his family's Nekos. After the two Nekos convince Kashou to let them stay and live with him, the three of them work together to run his shop, La Soleil. During the story, Kashou receives a couple of visits from his younger sister Shigure and the other four Nekos owned by their family.  [h1] Characters [/h1] [b]Chocola[/b] (ショコラ, Shokora) [i]Chocola is a cheerful and energetic brown-haired neko. She is Vanilla's twin sister and moved in with Kashou after he started his own business.[/i] [b]Vanille[/b] (バニラ, Banira) [i]Vanilla is a calm and quiet white-haired Neko. She rarely expresses her emotions. She loves her twin sister Chocola, and often follows her anywhere she goes. She and Chocola are the youngest of the Minaduki family nekos throughout most of the series.[/i] [b]Shigure Minaduki[/b] (水無月 時雨, Minazuki Shigure) [i]Kashou's younger sister. She appears to have romantic feelings for Kashou in an incestuous way. She and her older brother are the owners of the Minaduki family Nekos.[/i] [b]Azuki[/b] (アズキ) [i]Azuki is the oldest of the Minaduki family Nekos. Despite being the oldest, she is also the shortest and has a mischievous personality. However, she lives up to being the eldest catgirl by effortlessly managing and leading her sisters as they work in Kashou's cafe. She also has a tsundere personality. She is a Munchkin cat.[/i] [b]Maple[/b] (メイプル, Meipuru) [i]Maple is the second oldest of the Minaduki family Nekos. She has an independent/mature personality. She enjoying visiting cafes to try different food and drinks. She aspires to be a singer but is held back by her own lack of self-confidence as well as the prospect that she will only ever make it big because she is a catgirl. She is an American Curl.[/i] [b]Cinnamon[/b] (シナモン, Shinamon) [i]Cinnamon is the third oldest of the Minaduki family Nekos. She frequently interprets things in a sexual manner and ends up becoming aroused. She is closest to Maple and thus aspires to be by her side to support her life decisions. She is a Scottish Fold with purple hair.[/i] [b]Coconut[/b] (ココナツ, Kokonatsu) [i]Coconut is the third youngest of the Minaduki family Nekos. Other characters praise her for her "cool" personality, but she wishes she were cute rather than cool. She also tries to do more than she can to seem more like an older sister, as well as to not seem to burden to Kashou and the other catgirls. She has heterochromia, with her right eye being orange and left eye being blue. She is a Maine Coon.[/i] [b]Cacao[/b] (カカオ, Kakao) [i]Cacao is a character who debuted in the animated series. She has mint green hair and always wears a hat. She was formerly a homeless Neko before being brought into the Minaduki household by Chocola.[/i]  [h1] Storyline [/h1] ✔️ Excellent! It has a good story line, and it is 1/6 parts of the series.  [h1] Music & Sounds [/h1] ✔️ Good! My opinion it looks good, and i like all the sounds on the backgrounds.  ⠀

comentarios: [h1] Can be an Adult Game [/h1]  Nekopara Vol. 1 introduces players to a charming alternate reality where catgirls, or 'Neko,' seamlessly integrate into everyday life. These Neko possess human female bodies with adorable feline features like ears, tails, and subtle mannerisms. The story centers on Kashou Minaduki, a young man who departs from his family's traditional confectionery business to pursue his passion for baking. However, his plans are delightfully derailed when two of his family's loyal Neko, the energetic Chocola and the serene Vanilla, stow away in his belongings and follow him to his new home.  Nekopara Vol. 1 is a visual novel, meaning its focus is entirely on narrative delivery. Players should expect a linear experience with no branching storylines or gameplay elements beyond progressing the text and enjoying the accompanying visuals and music. The game excels in its lighthearted, slice-of-life storytelling, showcasing the endearing interactions between Kashou and the Neko. The narrative explores themes of independence, found family, and the challenges of adapting to a new life, all wrapped in a sugary-sweet package. While the premise is undeniably cute, it also sparks a degree of thoughtful contemplation. The game subtly raises questions about the societal implications of integrating non-human beings into everyday life, prompting players to consider the potential complexities of such a scenario.  It's important to note that Nekopara Vol. 1 contains suggestive themes and imagery. While the base game is generally suitable for mature teenagers, an optional adult patch is available for purchase, which significantly increases the explicit content. Therefore, a recommended age rating of 16+ for the base game and 18+ for the adult version is appropriate. Overall, Nekopara Vol. 1 serves as a delightful and engaging introduction to the Nekopara universe. Its charming characters, appealing art style, and lighthearted narrative make it a pleasant experience for fans of visual novels and those seeking a relaxing, feel-good story. It's a promising start to a unique and a new IP.  [h1] The game isn't an adult game without buying the adult patch from Steam or other ways. It doesn't change what happens in the game, you just see adult content. Honestly in the end, the adult content is just okay. It is still censored. [/H1]

comentarios: [h1] A sweet, lovely classic, with copious amounts of spice! (8/10) [/h1] (• Played with R18 Patch)  Yes, this is 10 years old and I’m late on jumping on the train. But personally I still think it holds up quite well in most regards. If you want to start delving into JPVNs with romcom and SOL elements, and want to see what the fuss is all about, I’d say this is still a fine title to consider! Doubly so if you appreciate catgirls (you should, they’re cute) or maid uniforms!  I do feel like everything is pretty surface level in terms of how the relationship develops and how the story progresses, but from a technical perspective, this is a very well-polished game that focuses on having brilliant art and VA at the very least. The start can also feel a bit weird / wishy-washy, especially how cold and distant Kashou seems to the girls at times in the first few chapters, but I guess it’s there for the sake of character development.  It also felt somewhat formulaic, in the sense that MC ends up being nice a bit to a girl for a little sweet talk moment, then [spoiler]they go in heat and smell something sweet off MC as a sign.[/spoiler]. Happens to Chocola, then soon after happens to Vanilla. Of course, there are other story beats outside of this, but these two being strung together back-to-back made it feel slightly repetitive, on top of the fact that “[i]come on, anyone could literally say that[/i]”.   Of course, them being catgirls is the saving grace that might let me suspend my disbelief a little bit and assume they are clingy and easily attached by nature. And also maybe this obvious disbelief is why devs released Vol 0 AND Vol Extra; to give more substantial reasoning to the romance that unfolds here, since based on the synopsis of those, they felt like Chocola and Vanilla needed to be given more limelight.  The game also features Shigure, the somewhat lovestruck little sister/trainer/’other real owner’ of the catgirls. Her scenes are fun, but her existence makes me go “[i]another one of these, huh[/i]”. Despite my limited knowledge in this sphere I know how notoriously somewhat-common it is to have a sister chara who crushes on MC. And I know some people would rather [i]not deal with that stuff[/i] so I thought it’s worth mentioning. It is pretty fine here though, since everything is one-way and MC doesn’t indulge her too much. But looking at the info about the upcoming game “After”, it is somewhat likely that she’ll be a slowburn, final LI.  The end scene is pretty heartfelt, although I notice some odd details in how [spoiler]the cop literally doesn’t care that there’s a very sick dude being out late at night and needing help.. They literally said “[i]alright I’mma head out.[/i]”[/spoiler] Literally tunnel-vision and doing the bare minimum, but I guess that’s par for the course for background characters.  The epilogue also very rightfully teases the fact that [spoiler]other catgirls are moving in too[/spoiler], so I’m looking forward to slowly trying the rest of the bundle!  [h3]Information:[/h3]  [b](•)Playtime Total: 7h10m13s[/b]. I don’t cut VA and am generally not rushing. Took me 1h until intro video, 1:28:0 until Bath CG, and 3:14:29 until first H CG.  From my timings, the [b]H scene accounts for 2 hours exactly[/b]. ([spoiler]35m for Chocola, probably also ~35 for Vanilla, and 50m for final scene[/spoiler])  [b](•)Kinetic Novel.[/b]  [b](•)A tinge of Yuri.[/b] Yes, they may be “[i]indulgent, male-gaze-enabling[/i]” kissing art, but it’s technically there nonetheless. Although Chocola & Vanilla treat each other more like dependent twin sisters (as they are), they seem to really love each other.  [h3](+) Pros/General Ratings:[/h3]  [b](+) Writing (7/10).[/b] I mean it’s just slice of life so nothing mindblowing, but it was fun to read. There’s some okay worldbuilding too with laws, narration describing the population at large accepting catgirls as companions, etc. . At least it’s a bit more than the bare minimum.  [b](+) Godly tier art (9/10).[/b] People are here for the anime CGs, myself included, and it did not disappoint. Of course I’m partially swayed by the fact that lots of what I saw are H Scenes, but even if you’re playing without patch, there’s also some beautiful date CGs here or them very cutely eating cake. There’s also a lot of cut-in images that makes things decently expressive; more than I initially expected. I do wish we got a few more of the girls actually in the kitchen doing work, but it is what it is.  [b](+) Lovely girls (7.7/10).[/b] Chocola and Vanilla are very good girls. They’re very earnest, and the sense of distance Vanilla brings to the table actually intrigues me quite a bit. Of course, they’re also cute in their own ways. It does sometimes feel like they’re very simple mass-appeal charas though; but maybe simple truly is the best!  [b](+)Animated Sprites[/b]. Some of the pauses in movement can feel a bit awkward and dated, but the fact that it’s mostly animated is nice.  [b](+) Good Voice Acting (8/10).[/b] Yep. Not much to be said except nice production value. I don’t know much about who’s-in-what, but at least I noticed Coconut sharing VA with Ditzy Demons’ Miyabi (Tezuka Ryouko) and I really love her voice. [strike]Guess that’s why I gotta get in on the sequels[/strike]. Chocola exudes real lovey-dovey sweetness. The whole cast is solid really.  [h3](-) Cons:[/h3]  [b](-) Still some typos.[/b] Yep. Even for something [u]this popular and 10 years old[/u], there’s still a couple of lines with missing words and wrong words. Although it’s rare enough that I feel like it’s better than some other newer titles, but it’s surprising that this is the case, considering the current landscape of other non-JPVN games being updated and fixed for typo issues. Maybe no one cares to report them for JPVNs and I won’t either, but I’ve done my part for some other titles at least. I’d figure this was popular enough that some would surely have already done it over time, but I guess not!  [b](-) Text Display jank.[/b] Sometimes text just shows a single word for me and the line stops loading entirely or advancing. Bringing up the backlog in these cases show the full line, but going back to the line shows the incomplete one. Dunno what is causing this on my end but it happens, in both cases of previous line being advanced via auto-play vs manual clicks. I do often re-enable and disable it via the auto play button, and have different text speeds between manual clicks & auto play despite basically doing both depending on whether the current line is voiced or not, so maybe that causes issues, but it’s annoying how unpolished this feature seems to me.  I guess it was par for the 2014 time and my expectations are colored by more modern, newer-year releases feeling smoother in this regard. I expected something this beloved to differentiate between Auto mode Text Speed vs Auto Mode Wait Time (how long to advance once the line is fully outputted) too as an aside, but I guess back then no one realizes these two could be different sliders.  [b](-) Deleting save files just causes the game to crash.[/b] ??? “Invalid Value / Time & Date” prompt shows up before the game closes on me… my brother.. why is that even relevant. I have no idea.  [b](-) Steam Screenshots during the bath H-CG doesn’t show text even if you want it to.[/b]I guess some publishers do some special stuff during these to avoid getting into problem with steam formerly (fine); and hence do some kind of censoring in intent, but in implementation something ended up going wrong. The only thing that gets hidden is the actual textbox/backlog while fully showing the CG in full display.  Of course, the actual H scenes will result in pixellated screenshots and that’s pretty standard in my limited experience. But still an oddity how the bath CG differs.  [h1]Overall, pretty standard and I’d still humbly somewhat recommend it![/h1]

comentarios: Nekopara Vol. 1 is a visual novel developed by NEKO WORKs, serving as the true beginning of the Nekopara series. It blends an endearing slice-of-life story with high-quality artwork, fully voiced characters, and an immersive presentation. This installment introduces players to the heartwarming yet comedic life of running a patisserie with adorable catgirls.    Nekopara Vol. 1 Review (Steam):  ⭐Story:   The game follows Kashou Minaduki, a young pastry chef who moves out to start his own patisserie, La Soleil. However, two of his family's catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla, sneak along and insist on staying with him. As he manages his bakery, players experience heartwarming, funny, and sometimes emotional moments with the catgirls. While the story is lighthearted and predictable, it excels in delivering wholesome and entertaining interactions.    ⭐Visuals and Art Style:   The artwork is absolutely gorgeous, featuring beautifully detailed backgrounds and expressive character sprites powered by the E-mote system, giving them lively animations. The character designs are polished and vibrant, making every scene visually delightful.    ⭐Audio and Voice Acting:   The game includes full Japanese voice acting for all the catgirls, making their personalities shine. The background music is relaxing and fits the cozy atmosphere of the patisserie setting, enhancing the overall experience.    ⭐Gameplay: As a kinetic visual novel, Nekopara Vol. 1 has no choices or branching paths—it’s a straightforward narrative experience. However, it does feature an interactive "petting system," allowing players to interact with the catgirls, adding a bit of engagement beyond just reading.    ⭐Replayability and Value: Since there are no alternate endings or choices, replay value is limited. However, fans of the series may revisit the game for its charming story, cute characters, and relaxing vibe. For newcomers, this is the best entry point into the Nekopara universe.    Final Score:   - Story: 7/10   - Visuals: 9.5/10   - Audio: 8.5/10   - Gameplay: 7/10   - Replayability: 6.5/10    Overall: 7.7/10    Conclusion:   Nekopara Vol. 1 is an excellent introduction to the series, offering a sweet and lighthearted story with stunning visuals and charming characters. While it lacks player choices, its immersive presentation and wholesome moments make it a must-play for visual novel and catgirl fans. If you enjoy cute slice-of-life narratives, this is a great pick!

comentarios: I'm replaying trough the Nekopara series for the second time now, and I felt like leaving a more elaborate review to anyone that might be interested in giving it a try.  [b] Nekopara Vol.1 [/b] is the first slice of a Visual Novel series about life with catgirls (and also running a patisserie). Each volume (game) moves the story forward and focuses on a different pair of catgirls, and this one is all about Chocola and Vanilla.  Reading trough the VN you can expect a very fun slice of life story, lovable and charismatic characters, amazing art with lively animated sprites, a great soundtrack, a lewd-cute romance and even optional NSFW content (included on the paid +18 dlc). If you enjoy any of this stuff, I recommend this VN for you!  Note that this is a linear VN, meaning that you don't have any dialogue or action options, and also meaning there's no character routes, so just sit back and enjoy the reading.  The story is divided into 8 chapters, and if I have to explain them, each one could be compared to an anime episode. I personally found it enjoyable to finish a game session in the end of a chapter, and then resume playing in the start of the next one.  [b] Nekopara Vol.1 [/b] has a free demo that includes all of chapter 1, so you should at least give it a try!

comentarios: Hey, let me tell you, NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is an absolute trip! If you’re into some cute catgirls and wholesome chaos, this is your jam. The art is chef's kiss—like, who knew a bunch of anime cats could be so... ahem... adorable? The story? Okay, okay, I’ll admit it, it’s a whole mood. I’m proud to say I played for the plot... for real. Don't @ me. It's sweet, funny, and lowkey heartwarming.  I got way more attached to these characters than I expected, not gonna lie. The banter is top-tier, and you'll be laughing, cringing, and maybe even getting a little emotional (yeah, I said it). It’s the perfect balance of absurdity and charm. Sure, it’s a visual novel, so not much action, but trust, you won’t care. Just sit back, relax, and enjoy the ride.  If you're here for something a lil' different, that doesn’t take itself seriously, this one's a winner. Grab it, enjoy it, and, yeah, I’m sticking with the "I played for the plot" excuse forever.

comentarios: By definition this isn't a game. It's more like an animated comic strip. I feel that this product being listed under games is misleading and should be sold as a simple animated manga. Also the rating is unfair. Nothing about anything I've seen would be considered 'Hentai'. While some of the conversation does discuss having sex the manga shows nothing inappropriate and aside from a few incestual comments from one or two characters the conversations are obscure enough to not be out of place. I don't think this is an animated manga appropriate for children, but I don't think it's engaging enough for adults. In all fairness I regret purchasing this.

comentarios: There comes a time in every man's life when he needs to look in the mirror and ask himself how exactly he got to that place. You have to truly reflect on the decisions you have made along the path that led you to the place of your final reckoning.  It's still not clear, even to me, why I bought this game. There's nothing wrong with it, with those nudity scenes it's perfectly stellar. But when you look at it as a choice, you realize how damaged I and the rest of humanity are.  What prompted me to buy a game like this? What part of my soul felt so empty that I thought a virtual girl could fill it? When I look into the infinite depths of my own loneliness, I see a pool of reflection. My face is not there, there is no face. There are only tears in that puddle, tears of shame, loss and confusion.  If it were up to me again, I know I would buy it in a heartbeat, I know I would load it up and skip the countless window prompts so I could get a single bite of the pornographic images that are available online. However, despite the abundance of naked virtual women waiting in the digital sphere, I chose to purchase this game and dedicate hours of my life to it. That time will never return to me, it is lost just like my soul and like time I fear never to find it again.  There is something broken inside me, something that desires sensations beyond my reach, something that moans every night knowing that there is no real princess, it is simply an illusion. In my quest to find meaning in this long life, I searched for the colorful lights and sounds of a world that only exists in a pop-up window on my computer.  I'm not sure what the moral of this review is, I'm not sure of my place within the universe, all I know is that no amount of virtual girls can cure the big rot that has plagued me I really need money for treatment...

comentarios: I DIDN'T KNOW THIS WAS A HENTAI! But that didn't matter as the full game is apparently locked behind DLC. (According to the negative reviews.) It had like maybe 2 kind of nudity scenes, but nothing was showing. Bless my eyes!  I didn't know anything about Nekopara when putting it into my wishlist. I saw the cute character designs and that it was a visual novel. Was blind to the tags. My husband bought me all the Nekoparas on a huge sale. Wish I played and discovered how I felt sooner so my husband could have gotten his money back. I'm sorry, Kenu!  Now I know this game is not targeted towards me with it being a hentai. I'm not going to review the game for it's NSFW.  The Problems:  1. The story is very bland and dialogue wasn't that interesting.  2. Listed as a visual novel, but has no dialogue options. 3. The catgirls literally act like cats in a human body. Could be a hentai thing, but I don't feel the need to f**k my cat. 4. Voice acting was cringe when they tried to act like cats. 5. The lore of the catgirls being pets, but can also be lovers is disgusting. Basically you are owning someone and for pleasure while they also happen to be your pet (bonus point: they can't get pregnant either to add to the fantasy).  6. It seems like they were trying to go for an innocence approach for Chocola and Vanilla (the main catgirls), but they come off as acting like 8 year olds. I believe they are still underage even in cat years. 7. The MC viewing Chocola and Vanilla as daughters and helped raised them, but still has sex with them. Even thinking that after sex too! Pedo behavior.  8. When Chocola goes into heat, Vanilla pressures the MC to have sex with her. Even saying that catgirls can get ill if not satisfied during this time.  9. Little sister lusts hard after the MC. And letting the MC get frisky with her pets. 10. Why is having sex with your pet a normal and okay thing in this world?  Good things about this product: 1. Character designs are great. Especially the contrasting colors for Chocola and Vanilla for being twins. 2. Voicing acting was good when they were not speaking like cringey cats. 3. Backgrounds are very polished and nice to look at. 4. Dialogue is very easy to read. (But still uninteresting.) 5. The art is gorgeous and probably the best selling point.

comentarios: This review is for the whole Nekopara series on steam.  Pros -great art -extremely moe -decent voice acting -cute slice of life story -little sister has a brother complex  Cons -no decisions / story branches -auto mode sometimes skips multiple lines of text -bad pacing -the split into multiple volume means entering your settings every volume and CGs are split between different games as well as paying for each volume including the three different paywalls to the H scenes -each volume is short enough to be read in one sitting -cant romance the sister  There's really not much to say about this. It was a good time reading it but there were no decisions basically making the save menu useless. This makes it feel like a shit manga with voice acting and awkward character animations. This game is pure moe trash which i love but if i'm paying for moe trash i want more out of it like in other visual novels with branching story lines or like in the neptunia series where you get a full game and moe trash. If i wanted to read and look at cute anime girls i would read manga (for free).   Worst of all there is no romancing the little sister and no little sister H scene. This is the offence that caused me to write this review.

comentarios: 09pm  I am a 54 year old mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my daughter, who is now 15. My daughter recently started Nekopara in less than a week, she had already played for over 12 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my daughter, as she is always out with her friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside her. I loaded into the game, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my daughter for help and she hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my daughter since my husband had died. This game has ever since brought my daughter and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my daughter many happy memories! 😊

comentarios: ok so first, I didn't go into this game thinking it was a porn game. I genuinely thought it was just a visual novel. So, I'll be reviewing it as one.   The Pros: the art, voice acting, and design of the game are put together very well. The art is super cute (besides the lewd stuff which is super nasty imo)   The Cons: HORRIBLE writing. Genuinely the characters are SO annoying, the worldbuilding makes no sense either. AND not to mention the incest shit?? You have a little sister who's obsessed with you AND you're like the father of the catgirls? But you have sex with them?? It's just so messed up. Gross sex shit aside, it's near impossible to actually play the game. I can't get over the oddly worried dialogue. It's so hard to read.   So in conclusion, if you're kinda weird and looking for a solid sex game, go for it I guess? But, if you're looking for an actual visual novel please stay away.   SUPER funny game to gift to a friend tho

comentarios: This game is the absolute peak of fiction. Nothing can ever, or will ever be released that will top this masterpiece of a series. The emotions that pass through ones body as they play through this game can not be replicated, and the colourful and whimsical nature makes it appeal all the more. The design of every last one of the characters is perfect, and shows their incredible dynamic with each other through typical tropes that all play off of each other incredibly well. This series has given a new lease on life and has shone a new perspective on how stories in fiction can be written. I will create a review for each game, and talk about the main characters in each separate game, starting with this one; Vol 1.

comentarios: Chocola: Chocola is one of the two poster catgirls for the NEKOPARA series, and her personality is built to shine in that role. Chocola is outgoing and ditzy in nature, being the second youngest of the Minaduki Household, Chocola is shown to lack a sense of direction, and blindly follows her intuition, heart, and of course, her Master. She is presented as one of the deuteragonists of the series along with her sister, Vanilla, and together they wreak havoc day in and day out. She is not very good at dealing with complicated matters, and tends to lean away from serious topics with quick topic changes and feigned ignorance. Those around her perceive her as clumsy and uninsightful, when she is instead a strong willed and inspired catgirl determined to help those around her. Chocola was abandoned at a young age and taken in by Kashou (MC) & Shigure (MC's Sister). The character development from her starting as a scared, young soul, and developing into the shining star catgirl at La Soleil is a great decision, as she takes over co-lead at La Soleil. Throughout the games we are shown time and time again why Chocola is so strong willed and is always willing to fight for what she thinks is right. Chocola's go with the flow attitude makes her shine in almost every major plot-point throughout the series as she is not afraid to speak her mind, even if she isn't the most insightful while doing so. Chocola is a happy-go-lucky catgirl who even when sad, can be swung by a simple change of scenery of topic, although she is capable of being genuinely sad at points (As shown while they try and convince Kashou to let them stay at La Soleil). While she most definitely loves her sister, her love is not as outwardly displayed as Vanilla's to Chocola which is a nice contrast differing from both of their character's normal styles of interaction. The two later entires that come first in the series, Vol. 0, & Extra both help expand on why Chocola loves her Master (Kashou) so much. They detail how he helped them settle in to the Minaduki household and made them feel safe by taking time out of his days to spend with them. The story of Vol. 0 follows Chocola trying to cope with not being able to see her Master as much, as he is working on his Patisserie skills. This plot-point, while developed later, does help tie up lose ends to the story as to why they wanted to follow Kashou to the point of shipping themselves in boxes across to his new shop.

comentarios: Vanilla: Vanilla is simply amazing. She is Chocola's identical twin, and almost all of her personality involves being exactly that. She follows Chocola as if it her job, and her only goal in life is to make sure that Chocola is happy, while staying with her. The two twins of the Minaduki household could not be more different in nature; while Chocola is energetic and upbeat, Vanilla prefers the more laid back approach, while still maintaining similar tastes as her sister. Similar to Chocola, Vanilla does not like serious topics, but chooses to use quick witted humour and distraction tactics as opposed to feigning ignorance to avoid such discussions. She is often portrayed as the more responsible of the pair, and always seems to be in the right place at the right time. As she is Chocola's twin sister, she too was taken in by the Minaduki household after being abandoned by their previous owners. Having such a similar upbringing to Chocola makes them share a lot of similarities, but their personal tastes and styles could not be more different. Chocola's happy go lucky attitude starkly contrasts Vanilla's sharp wit and "I'll do things my way" style of living. The want for independence but strong need to be next to her sister makes her the most "Catlike" of the 6 main catgirls. Vanilla's nature extends to how she acts, even around her family. She struggles to express emotions and maintains a monotonous voice throughout every entry of the series. This causes her to be often misunderstood as she is quite intelligent and oftentimes makes the most realistic comparisons and insights. The later released Vol. 0 and Extra versions continued to explain her complex backstory, showing her intelligence stemming from a young age, although she was not as prevalent as most of the other catgirls in those two entries.

comentarios: In Conclusion the two poster catgirls of NEKOPARA start the progression of character building in this series, and start incredibly strong by giving each their moments to shine, and also knowing when to take steps back and let others shine in their desired roles. NEKOPARA is a one of a kind game that has stood the test of time, and even improved in both storytelling and art with their newer entries.

comentarios: So I'm only on chapter 3, so I will update when I get further in the game! I'm gonna make this a serious review though, so.  Here's the things I like about this game so far: - The sprite art is really cute (Usually, will elaborate later) - The game has cat logic down to a pretty solid degree. - It's pretty cute watching Chocola and Vanilla going around being Chocola and Vanilla. - The other art in the game is also very pretty, from backgrounds to CGs and outfit design. - *Great* use of onomatopoeia everywhere  Here's what I don't like, though: - Major ambiguity on Chocola and Vanilla's ages. I get it that they age differently than both cats and humans, but the ambiguity between whether they're adults or children is way too major at times. - Kashou often says that Chocola and Vanilla are like daughters or little sisters to him, which feels weird considering how the game wants you to sexualize them. - Kashou often infantilizes Chocola and Vanilla, which feels weird sometimes when they act younger. - The sprites are really well done! But sometimes when Chocola's eyes go wide when she's looking at you head-on, she looks *really* uncanny. This is usually not the case when Chocola's head is at a 3/4ths angle. Sometimes when Vanilla looks to the left at Chocola when her head is at a 3/4ths angle, her eyes look like they're looking in two different directions.  I'll mark this review as recommended, but this game really isn't something I would recommend to just anyone. Maybe if that person can overlook the weird age ambiguity and dynamic between Chocola, Vanilla, and Kashou, then maybe, but I dunno.

comentarios: [h3]TLDR at the bottom for those who respect their own time.[/h3]  I'm a huge sucker for all things cute and the art for the Nekopara games is adorable!  The plot however..? [i]Eh...[/i] The relationship between Kashou and his catpanions really could have used more development as there's hardly any chemistry between them (literally the only reason they end up in a relationship is because the catgirls go into heat, like that's pretty much it.) I feel as if the characters never got to grow, both as individuals and in their relationships with each other, it's a bit of a shame, really, but maybe that's not what NEKO WORKs was trying to accomplish, and that's okay. Still, i was hoping for that "Oh thank GODS they finally kissed!" moment, which i was left a bit disappointed, as i'm sure it would have very much enriched the overall plot and enhanced the [i]"plot"[/i] scenes.  Speaking of... the ""PLOT"" here is of fine quality; the art is stunning and erotic af, the music suits the mood, and the voice acting really sells it (No other comments, easy 8.5/10 macaroons.)  Also, can we talk about the music? Like yeah yeah it does it's job of setting the tone for the game rather well, but tracks like Cat Work and Nya Soliel are straight up bangers! Great for easy listening and perfect for vibing to while snacking on your favorite pastry. (also also, there's a titty elasticity meter, do with that as you will but it's not really my kind of thing lol.) Still was hoping for a more romantic edge, but I enjoyed Vol. 1 a bit more than I thought I would... at least enough for me to move on to Vol. 2!  Thanks for your time dear reader, and farewell!  [h2]TLDR:[/h2] The [b]plot[/b] is good, but the actual plot could be better. The music and art are lovely and cute, [strike]also I love Maple and Coconut very much![/strike] I enjoyed my time at the cat cafe, and i feel like if you're reading this, there's a chance you will too!

comentarios: Bought this years ago and didn't get past the first few chapters. They were quite boring and there seemed to be little to no plot. Now returned to it and it was worth it. Doesn't seem to have other bugs or problems.

comentarios: [h1]This review was written by [/h1] [h1] [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44830234-Hot-or-Not-Reviews/] Hot or Not Reviews [/url] [/h1] [h3] If you liked this review, make sure to give us a follow! [/h3]  [b] NOTE: My playthrough was played with the NSFW DLC! My gameplay experience therefore may differ from yours! [/b] [b] See my review for the Nekopara Vol 1. NSFW content [/b] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Zacie/recommended/947650/] here[/url].  🔥HOT🔥 Nekopara Vol. 1 is a japanese voice acted visual novel (English, Chinese, Japanese subtitles) which is the first entry in the Nekopara series of visual novels. This game follows Kashou, who opens his confections shop after moving out of home. Little does he know, when unpacking boxes he finds two of his families catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla. Despite his best efforts, Chocola and Vanilla stay in the shop and work together to run the shop.  The game has 7 main characters (Excluding the MC) which are introduced at the start of the story, being the two catgirls who are the focus of this volume, Chocola and Vanilla - alongside your sister Shigure and her four catgirls, Cinnamon, Coconut, Azuki and Maple. Shigure is the only character besides Chocola and Vanilla who appears multiple times throughout the story. Shigure's catgirls only make two appearances, one for introduction to the characters and the other for eluding the second game's [spoiler] introduction to the rest of the girls working at the cafe, Patisserie La Soleil (Nicknamed Neko Paradise at the end of the VN.)[/spoiler]. This game took me 2.5 hours to read, although for a slow reader can take about 5 hours to read. The game has adjustable text speed which also allowed me to read faster, with using both auto and manual reading at just shy from the fastest text speed.   Without getting into spoilers, the game focuses on the relationship which forms between the two cats, Chocola and Vanilla and their backstory, obtaining bells (simply catgirl citizenship) alongside their relationship with Kashou. The game also slightly delves into some of Shigure's story - although this isnt fully explored. The artwork for the game is very high quality, having both opening and endings (with their own unique songs!), scene segway cards and CG's. The writing for the game is quite standard for a visual novel, using words you'd expect for an anime style VN, nothing outstanding in this department.   Overall, NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a high quality visual novel which with it's lovable cast which gets you invested in their stories and high production quality in bot it's SFX & artwork, I can certainly recommend this for both visual novel novices or experienced readers.

comentarios: Look, don’t think too hard about it.  Nekopara is a kinetic (linear story) visual novel featuring a lot of cute cat girls with about a length of 6-7 hours.   The story itself is fine, there were some good moments in it but no way is anyone actually playing this just for that. The art / visuals on the other hand are great and is definitely what carries the series. Voice acting is good as well, they do a great job with their characters. As a special mention, I really liked the UI / menu design, it fits the theme and is easy to navigate.  If you like cute things, great. If you like catgirls, even better. If you feel ashamed at yourself by buying this remember, there are over 22,000 reviews on this game here on Steam as of writing this. It doesn’t matter if they’re all joke reviews, that’s still a lot.  If you end up enjoying Nekopara, more power to you. I know I did and I’ll definitely be playing the other volumes in the future.

comentarios: The story of one dude who will bravely decide that, yes, he will have sex with his pet-daughters. (No but seriously, he likens them to his daughters multiple times)  This didn’t do it for me. I wanted to make sure I wouldn’t be missing out on anything so I sped through it, but I won’t be continuing.  There’s no meaningful character development, no choices at all (aside from whether to enable explicit content and how much to make the boobs shake in animations), and no conflicts. Also, the extras menu seems to be a bit broken (played on steam deck)  The real ecchi stuff doesn’t happen until chapter 5 of 8, so you’ll be waiting half the game for it.  This game caters to the fetish it was named for and nothing else. If you’re on the fence or only kind of like it, hopefully this can be the difference maker

comentarios: What a cute visual novel! There are so many things I love about it. It's definitely not perfect, as I found myself extremely uncomfortable by the incest themes and the ethics of the ownership of the catgirls. However, the pros outweigh the cons for me. The music is one thing that really stood out to me. It's always an important factor in a visual novel in my opinion, but it really stood out here. The voice acting was also just so good! Additionally, I really fell in love with the aesthetics; the art style is very cute with detailed sprites (with animation that I don't often see in VNs that really brought the characters to life) and the CGs were simply beautiful. Also, the general bakery/cake and maid themes are so moe! Finally, I must praise the game for its UI. One thing I love in a VN is its ability to be customised to the preferences of the player and this game has a very good settings page, allowing you to adjust to your comfort. Plus the P button and bounciness setting was enjoyable  ^.^

comentarios: I wish there was a neutral choice for this game so, instead, I'll follow suit for all the people that up-voted. comentarios: Nekopara is nothing short of a masterpiece that has profoundly impacted my life in ways I could never have imagined. From its breathtaking graphics to its compelling storyline and immersive gameplay, this game is a work of art that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming.  The first thing that struck me was the sheer beauty of the game's world. The attention to detail in every pixel is awe-inspiring. It's a place where you can lose yourself for hours, exploring every nook and cranny, and marveling at the intricate landscapes, from lush forests to desolate wastelands.  But Nekopara isn't just about visual splendor; it's about the emotional journey it takes you on. The characters are so well-developed that I found myself caring deeply about their fates. Their struggles and triumphs resonated with me on a personal level, reminding me of the strength of the human spirit.  The gameplay is a seamless blend of challenging puzzles, heart-pounding action sequences, and moments of quiet reflection. It's not just a game; it's an experience that forces you to think, adapt, and grow. It taught me valuable lessons about perseverance, problem-solving, and the importance of teamwork.

comentarios: [h1] NEKOPARA: Catnip for the Curious, and Well... More! [/h1] Welcome to the whimsical world of NEKOPARA, where catgirls reign supreme, and the plot takes a backseat to, well, some purr-plexing assets! 🐾  If you're in it for the feline-friendly fun, this visual novel will have you questioning whether you're a true cat lover or simply an enthusiast of...round shapes. Yes, we're talking about the NEKOPARA characters' ample assets. The creators have clearly decided that the cats in this game got more than their fair share of milk because, seriously, those proportions are nothing short of awe-inspiring.  The catgirls themselves are a sight to behold, and not just because of their adorable ears and tails. NEKOPARA boldly goes where few cat-based stories have gone before, putting the 'ecchi' in 'meowchii.' The bouncy physics of certain anatomical features could easily rival a trampoline park – talk about defying the laws of gravity with a furry twist!  The narrative is like the catnip that keeps you coming back for more, weaving a tale of patisseries, sisterly love, and a generous helping of double entendres. But let's be honest, the real stars of the show are the characters'...umm, personalities. They're just so well-rounded!  So, if you're looking for a game that embraces the philosophy of "plot over plot," and you have a penchant for catgirls with, shall we say, impressive assets, then NEKOPARA might just be the purr-fect match for you. Get ready for a tail-twitching, head-turning adventure that's bound to leave you feline fine! 🐱✨

comentarios: Some negative experiences, you just have a speech lined up for. Because something wonderful or at least interesting was on the line, and you want to vent the loss of the baby with the bathwater.  But for Nekopara? This kinetic visual novel that has just taken Steam by storm?  It has been a while since I have met something that somehow manages to be so underwhelming and uninteresting and yet quite so disgusting. Such so, that I don't even feel much need to copy-paste most of the copious notes I've taken as to why this is one of the most noxious, revolting, dislikable pieces of trash I've ever entertained on my hard drive.  But let me share a few.  There are major incestuous themes or at least implications that go unpunished, even presented as wholesome or pleasant; the "catgirls" are *nothing* like cats - the things in this VN are way too friendly, loyal, and affectionate to have *anything whatsoever* to do with felines - and there is generally an atmosphere and worldbuilding core of abuse in glittery paint. Aside from the incest, or at least incest-coded interactions, these human girls with cat features are "owned", living as slaves, as living playthings, and it's played up as this wholesome thing. And the writers have the gall to try to push some BS that they're actually more cat than human, "because ears and tail." It's like an excuse for a right-wing political policy; so stupid and insufficient to allay the elephant in the room it's supposed to explain away, delivered so confidently and unapologetically it either forces you to go along with it or sickens you to your gut. Or both.  __  But okay, let's say you're kind of feeling in the mood for an "Arabamu" lewd setup and you think the Emancipation Proclamation was a mistake. Well, what's wrong with Nekopara then?  Plenty, frankly. The story is underwhelming and uninteresting, just a day-by-day with no evident stakes and it basically being anime people doing anime things until you get to lewd scenes. I'd be up for a slice-of-life, if it's interesting, but Nekopara isn't.  The characters themselves, which are supposed to be the meat of the experience, apparently, get redundant and annoying, really fast; their interactions and dialogue might be bearable, even sparsely likable, in a different sort of VN, but for a game wie're here for the lewds for and we know it? And one *THIS LONG*? They're just obnoxious and don't add anything interesting to the plot or social atmosphere.  Speaking of lewd? Perhaps the biggest outrage of all is that it's not even in here, by default. You have to pay the whole price of the VN again, just to see what is probably only two or three scenes that I bet I could easily look up on a seedy website if I wanted to. It's insulting. Yes, I dislike that the dialogue seems to be incest-coded, but if you're going to put that in a game you are expressly selling for its lewd content, at least have the stones to double down and put your lewd content in as part of the main, whole purchase, lock, stock, and barrel.  Oh, did I say game? Excuse me. This isn't even a game. It's a "kinetic visual novel". There's no option to interact with the story or characters in any way. This just plays in one direction, with the same outcome, each time. This is basically a porn video if you ever thought "gee, I sure wish these porn videos had *more* talking heads, had most of their action in subtitles, and that I had to regularly click to make it play instead of clicking the once and just watching" - oh, and where you have to buy the video, then buy it *again* to see the actual *porn* in it.  And for gosh sakes, even the worldbuilding isn't worth a dime. The aforementioned genetic excuse they pull out of their ass for the girls' being cats is just the tip of the iceberg. There are stupid rules about the arrest of these "cat" girls, a "family" of eight somehow surviving on a singular traditional candy shop...  For hell's sake, even though this takes place in a bakery, and the Kashou guy presents himself as being all qualified and set up as a proper baker, through and through, I am convinced he's a fraud. He calls a Sponge Cake batter a "dough".an eyebrow-raiser but forgivable.  But wrapping it up and saving it for later!? WRAPPING! UP! *SPONGE CAKE*! BATTER! and SAVING IT FOR LATER!? I am in an Advanced Baking course as I type this (just got back, a bit of a coincidence now that I think about it) and this is one thing we DO NOT DO WITH SPONGE CAKES!  ___  If this were some obscure niche VN tucked in Steam's dark corners, maybe I wouldn't feel this angry. But the fact this is so popular that Steam expressly merchandises animated avatar images and other things about it, and its pics are all over the place for anything to do with lewd games or sci-fi cartoon girls to date? That is insulting. There are a hundred games that deserve stardom more than this - NSFW and SFW alike.  If you really want to spend ten - or depending on how desperate you are, twenty- dollars on a frustrating ghost of an experience when you could buy much better ones for five dollars or see a much longer one for free, go for it. Just don't say I didn't warn you.

comentarios: People who only watched the anime: aw, what a cute and wholesome story. People who played the VNs: do they know?  [h1] Introduction [/h1]  Nekopara Vol. 1 is a slice-of-life visual novel, and it's the first of a series of four visual novels (excluding the prequels, Nekopara Extra and Nekopara Vol. 0). It even has an anime adaptation for those who want to check it out. Being a slice-of-life story, it isn't a plot driven story by any stretch of the imagination, but this means that the characters need to be likable at the very least. Lets see if there are any merits to this game.  [h1] Worldbuilding [/h1]  Surprisingly, the worldbuilding of this game is solid and consistent. The game is set in modern Japan, and has similar, if not the same, rules of the real world. The difference is that catgirls are a thing. As a side note, some people think catgirls belong to the category of furry, which is wrong. Catgirls belong to kemonomimi, which are human, save of the animal ears. The game describes very consistently the characteristics of catgirls, the rules to which they abide and their influence on human society. The only gripe I have with the worldbuilding is that those elements are described mostly through exposition dumps instead of dialogue that flows naturally with the story and the characters. Another thing I noticed is that the absence of catboys, because the game establishes that catgirls can get pregnant, but not through a human, so that means that catboys must exist, but they are never mentioned. Something to think about.  [h1] The plot (or lack thereof) [/h1]  The story is simple. It's about a pastry chef that wants to open and run his own bakery, in opposition to what his parents wanted, and a very peculiar kind of employees join him to work at said bakery. Then the story focuses on the relationship between the two star catgirls and his new owner. Overall, the writing is solid, but not stellar, but there is a plot hole at the end of the story in which a character says something that contradicts something they previously said, and that facilitated the drama that followed. The pacing was good and the tonal shifts were spot on. The dialogue is good overall, but... why dialogue during H-scenes is so cringy? I may never know.  [h1] The characters [/h1]  The characters of this game, save one, are static, and, in the context of a slice-of-life story, it isn't a bad thing. The thing that matters is that the characters are consistently characterized and need to have distinct personality traits. Note that the names of the catgirls are always of ingredients used regularly in bakery. There are in total six catgirls (plus one that is a side character), but the main subjects of this story in particular are Chocola and Vanilla. They are very endearing characters. Chocola is a catgirl who wear her emotions on her sleeve and it has a very upbeat personality. Vanilla is more subdued but her deadpan jokes and the way she conceals what she really feels is, like I said, endearing. Regarding the main character, Minaduki Kashou (he will become a very, very lucky guy), undergoes a small change, because he wanted to run his bakery on his own, showing his selfishness, but then he accepted the help of Chocola and Vanilla. Shigure, his younger sister, is a total brocon. I'll leave it at that. Overall, the characters, especially Chocola and Vanilla, are very likable characters, but Kashou can be a bit boring at times.  [h1] Presentation [/h1]  The art direction is in the middle of the pack. Not bad, but not excellent either. Character artstyle, though, is very good, whether be in event CGs or the animated models, and the animations are very well done, expressive and life-like, and the way the ears of the catgirls perked up or drooped based on their emotional state is a nice little detail, plus, it looks very cute. The voice acting is also very good, the music fits the tone and the situation nicely, and the H-scenes are also excellent, though I wished that the scenes were at 60 fps, because in every other situation, the game ran at the same framerate as the refresh rate of my monitor (165 fps in the case of my gaming laptop and 240 fps in the case of my gaming PC). The player can also change between Traditional Chinese, English and Japanese text on the fly. The game also gives the player the option to adjust jiggle physics. Nice. Push "P" to see the effects.  In conclusion:  [b] Pros: [/b]  -Soild worldbuilding, with small exceptions. -Endearing and likable characters. -Good presentation overall (including H-scenes)  [b] Cons: [/b]  -Some plot issues at the end of the story. -Main character can be a bit boring. -At 10 hours, is a bit too short for the price (base game and 18+ DLC).  So, all in all, the game has enough merits to earn my recommendation. If you expected good storytelling in this game, then you are looking in the wrong place. Slice-of-life stories don't need traditional storytelling, only cute and likable characters doing cute things (and some extremely lewd things in this case), and this game delivers on that regard. Also, the presentation is worthy of praise, but I strongly recommend to wait for a good discount on the base game and the 18+ DLC, so you can get more for your money.

comentarios: This game is absolutely horrendous. Pretty much any visual novel can be expected to be fetishistic an stereotypical, but this is a fine example of these issues. There are numerous instances where the dialogue suddenly feels extremely stilted because some sexual implication is brought up out of nowhere, and especially when mentioned by one of the more innocent characters, these jokes and impications feel extremely out of place. Obviously it's an ecchi/18+ game, but you shouldn't have to throw innuendos into every single conversation like that. Literally a moments thought about this universe's logic reveals how actually fucked up it is. I mean, you essentially OWN other human beings - or at the very least, sentient beings who are shown to be pretty much equally capable to humans given the right environment. There's also the extremely obvious incestuous obsession of the MC's younger sister, which by the way, they do no efforts to excuse, even specifically stating that she is A. blood related and B. quite a bit younger than the MC in another game. An speaking of age gaps, did i mention that Vanilla and Chocola are cannonically NINE MONTHS OLD? They also act basically like children, and it's clear from the dialogue that they have only recently reached sexual maturity, so they are probably 16 year-olds in human years AT BEST. In addition, MC also raised them and is said to veiw them like younger sisters. Literally how much creepier can you get? Oh right, they are also legally his possesions. EW. So yeah, this game is absolutely the worst I have ever, EVER played.  That being said, they are all incredibly cute and god i want their wardrobes so bad. This series is probably my guiltiest pleasure ever.  nyanyanya nya nyanya nnya nyan nya nyannyanyan nyan nyan nya nyanya! nyanyanya nya nyanyanaynya!!! NYANYANYA!! :3

comentarios: When I played Vol. 0, I made the joke that I had many unanswered questions regarding the existence and status of catfolk in this world. I fully expected it to just be glossed over or handwaved, to be honest. Now I just feel like a fool.  Imagine my genuine surprise when the mental checklist of out-there, absurd worldbuilding requests I planned to joke about was slowly ticked off throughout the game. Things like the view of catfolk/human relationships, the rate of aging, catfolk's status in society, whether or not catfolk and people can reproduce, etc. Why would a cutesy eroge bother even mentioning any of this, I thought? Hence why my absurdist review would mark that as a faux complaint. But it's all there, and as subtly horrific as it should be. And I love that.  In all seriousness, it's very cute. The ero scenes are whatever, I'd honestly say not to bother spending the extra cash on em if you're on the fence about it. Ultimately, though, it's your call whether you want this as a hardcore eroge or a cutesy romance story. I can respect the fact that it caters to both crowds.

comentarios: A VN that is pleasant enough and funny at certain points but very abruptly changes tones much quicker than expected. This is short so there isn't much time to provide depth to the characters and the story could've used some work for it to make more sense and have a better payoff.  For instance, there's a point where the MC is essentially on death's door and passed out in bed. The two catgirls run out for help and then get into a bit of trouble. Minutes later, MC has hopped out of bed, is perfectly fine to head outside, somehow goes to the exact spot the girls are at and ends up saving them. You can't tell me a character is at death's door and then, with absolutely nothing changing, suddenly have that character up and running around. It makes no sense.  Anyway, pleasant enough but needed fleshed out more.

comentarios: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

comentarios: I like visual novels. I like catgirls. I like boobs and sex and sexy things. This has nice visuals. There's even a  slider to control the amount of boob bounce if that's your thing.  I'm not in any way a prude.  But there's no actual choices or gameplay involved, its just a straight auto-playing game.  Basically an anime with no budget.  And that's fine, visual novels are what they are, not all of them need branching paths or illusion of choice. They hae a particular story to tell, its a novel rather than a dating sim.  That's fine.  What's not fine is the main relationship.  The two main characters are treated and aged like children.  They're mentally cats.  They're sisters.  They call the player their master.  The player character EXPLICITLY thinks of them as his "daughters". And then they have sex. It's just really gross.  Incest, pedophilia AND bestiality all in one package.  The story was kind of cute at first but then they started making long analogies about flowers having sex and then one of them being in heat and it just got really squicky.  I feel like I'm on a watch list now.

comentarios: I somewhat wish there were a 'meh' rating here on Steam, but as it stands:  Do you like pretty anime? Do you like h-games? Visual novels? Harems, cat-girls or slightly animated sex scenes? If so, you'll probably like this game, which is really just a visual novel you read through. I do wish there were some more interactive elements to this game (choices like in dating sims or interactions with characters like in other h-games).   My issue is that the two main catgirls (Chocola and Vanilla) refer to themselves in the third person all the time and it annoys the shit out of me. Also, Shigure, as the main character's little sister is really.. a bit much. The rest of the catgirl crew is pretty neat and I do look forward to maybe learning more about them in future games. Hentai scenes are pretty nice, but due to Japanese law regarding censorship, the genitalia are censored, which is a bummer.  Favorite chapter of this is probably Ch. 8, which was endearing and contained no h-scenes at all. And the set up for the sequel was cute.
